A B S T R A C T
Efficient information management is pivotal for the effective execution of spatial planning pro-
jects, yet many encounter hurdles stemming from disjointed information systems and processes.
In this article, authors consider the intricacies of information management within the realm of
spatial planning, leveraging insights from the multifaceted MAKING-CITY project to elucidate
common challenges and propose innovative solutions. The proposed conceptual model for an
integrated information management system offers a holistic approach, aiming to eliminate
weaknesses inherent in existing information landscapes by seamlessly integrating diverse infor-
mation components into a unified framework. By facilitating robust communication channels and
synchronizing the actions of all project participants and stakeholders, this model enhances
collaboration, streamlines workflows, and fosters informed decision-making. Importantly, the
adaptability and versatility of developed model ensure its applicability across various spatial
planning initiatives, offering a scalable solution to address the evolving demands of urban
development projects. Through a meticulous examination of real-world challenges and practical
solutions, this article contributes to the advancement of information management practices in
spatial planning, laying the groundwork for more efficient, sustainable, and inclusive urban
development processes in today's dynamic landscape.

1. Introduction
In the times of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, which is characterized by integrating advanced technologies in manufacturing and
global digital transformation, namely the worldwide adoption of digital technologies to enhance operations and processes, information
is the main tool and the main weapon of many organizations (businesses, public authorities, academic institutions, etc.) [1,2,3].
Numerous studies in the field of management have addressed the significance and standing of information management within or-
ganizations [4,5,6,7,8,9,10]. But, on the other hand, research shows that without proper information management, any organisation
begins to lose control over the real state of affairs both in the internal and external environments [4,11,12]. Therefore, for its existence
and sustainable development, organizations need to receive information promptly and use it to make effective, evidence-based

One of the important areas of activity in the development of modern society, which requires the use of modern approaches of
information management, is spatial planning projects. Spatial planning is used by public authorities and local governments to in-
fluence the future location and distribution of territories, population distribution, and the implementation/conduct of various ac-
tivities in space. Such planning is needed to balance the potentially competing needs of the economy, society, and the preservation of
the environment [9] Spatial planning project refers to a structured and strategic initiative undertaken by governments, organizations,
or communities to manage and organize the use of land and resources within a specific geographical area. Spatial planning projects
primarily focus on organizing physical spaces, emphasizing land use and sustainability, often spanning large areas and years, involving
government, communities, and interest groups, and requiring adherence to government regulations and environmental standards. It is
the main difference between this kind of project and other kinds of projects like IT or construction [13].
Effective spatial planning project decisions depend on the availability of timely and reliable spatial information. Spatial data has
become indispensable across various facets of urban development, planning, and management. Its growing significance can be
attributed to recent advancements in spatial data acquisition, including satellite remote sensing and the Global Navigation Satellite
System, as well as improved data management through Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and database tools. The challenge lies in
overcoming information barriers and enabling users both within and outside these domains to discover, access, and utilize this in-
formation to enhance decision-making, business outcomes, and customer services. Spatially enabled web-based services are opening
fresh opportunities to engage citizens more closely in consultations and land administration activities [14].
The tool that has shown practical effectiveness, that can be used for information management of spatial planning projects is an
information management system. Information systems are integrated sets of components that collect, process, store, and distribute
information to support decision-making, coordination, control, analysis, and visualization in an organization [15].
To date, scientific research has not presented the study of the problem of creating a unified information management system in
spatial planning projects. Therefore, the authors propose to consider the creation of such a system through the prism of the inter-
national project Making City.
2. Research goal and objectives
The main goal of the article is to build a conceptual model of an information management system in the spatial planning project.
The model proposed in the article should help to eliminate weaknesses in the existing information space of the project by integrating
different information components into a single system that will connect and synchronize the actions of all participants and stake-
holders of the project. Such a system will accelerate the interaction processes, as well as reduce the degree of uncertainty in the project,
which will improve the spatial planning processes. The developed model can be adapted and applied to different types of spatial
planning projects.
To achieve this goal, the article outlines three main objectives.
Objective 1. Analyse the existing information management system of the MAKING-CITY project.
The first objective is to conduct a thorough analysis of the existing information management system used in the MAKING-CITY
project. This will involve reviewing project documents, conducting interviews with project team members, and gathering feedback
from stakeholders. The aim is to identify the strengths and weaknesses of the existing system, which will inform the development of the
conceptual model.
Objective 2. Analyse previous research materials.
The second objective is to review the current research on problem-solving available in the field of information management and
spatial planning. This will involve a thorough literature review and an examination of case studies. The aim is to identify the most
effective problem-solving decisions that can be integrated into the conceptual model.
Objective 3. Develop a conceptual model of the information management system.
The third objective is to develop a conceptual model of the information management system that can be used in spatial planning
projects. This model will consider the strengths and weaknesses of the existing system, along with the authors' previous experience.
The aim is to provide a practical solution that can be implemented in real-world projects.
Following the study's goals and objectives, the article follows the next structure.
1. Introduction. This section provides a general overview of the importance of information management and its relevance for business.
It introduces the research question the study aims to address and outlines the structure of the article.
2. Research goal and objectives. This section describe the main goal and objectives of the research.
3. Materials and Methods This section summarizes relevant studies, research, and literature that are conducted on information
management of spatial planning projects. Also in this section, the authors clarify the issues or challenges that prompted the research
and provide context for the subsequent research materials.
4. Results. This part introduces a conceptual model for an information management system in spatial planning projects. It explains the
key definitions, components, and principles of this model.
5. Discussion. In this part the article delves into the findings of the study, analyzing and interpreting the application of the conceptual
model of information management systems for spatial planning projects on the example of the international project MAKING-CITY.
6. Conclusions. The final section of the article summarizes the key takeaways and conclusions drawn from the study's findings.

The research method in this article appears to be conceptual, focusing on the development of a conceptual model based on existing
knowledge and literature. Conceptual research is characterized by the examination and analysis of pre-existing information about a
specific subject, without the involvement of practical experimentation. It primarily deals with abstract concepts and ideas.
The article discusses the development of a conceptual model for an information management system in spatial planning projects,
using the international project MAKING-CITY as a prominent case study [16]. The study involves the analysis of existing literature and
research in the fields of information management, spatial planning, and related areas. It also presents a conceptual framework for the
information management system, including definitions, components, and functionality.
3. Materials and methods
3.1. Literature review
The concept of information management in organizations has garnered significant attention in previous research. For instance,
White [17] defines information management as the systematic collection and dissemination of information from various sources, with
a primary focus on organizing, controlling, processing, evaluating, and reporting these activities. This encompasses all forms of
valuable information, whether originating within or outside the organization. Furthermore, Detlor [18] elaborates on information
management as encompassing the control over information creation, acquisition, organization, storage, distribution, and utilization,
emphasizing its role in facilitating efficient and effective information access, processing, and utilization. A comprehensive analysis
conducted by Altındag and colleagues [4] highlights the diversity of definitions for information management in the organizational
context. These definitions vary, including one from Ruuska [8], which emphasizes the importance of how information is obtained, and
efficiently used, and the development of applications for its management. Canbaz [5] and his colleagues, on the other hand, emphasize
the unity of processes involved in obtaining, transforming, producing, and disseminating information to achieve organizational goals.
In addition to these definitions, it's important to acknowledge the significance of information management in the broader context of
project management. Previous studies (e.g., Refs. [7,9,19]) underline that information management plays a pivotal role in achieving
organizational purposes and enhancing individual expertise.
These definitions collectively underline the multifaceted nature of information management, spanning a range of processes, from
acquisition to utilization. These processes typically comprise stages such as establishment, acquisition, classification, storage, transfer,
sharing, and evaluation within an integrated information management system [20]. Moreover, the crucial role of information man-
agement systems, integrating people, processes, and technology, cannot be underestimated in supporting an organization's operations,
management, and decision-making functions. Effective use of collected information is central to these systems.
Opoku and Enu-Kwesi [21] emphasize the importance of establishing policies and strategies for data creation, storage, processing,
distribution, and use as part of information management practices while highlighting the relationship between information man-
agement practices and an organization's innovation, growth, and financial performance.
The literature also underscores the significance of spatial planning information management. Effective spatial planning projects
rely heavily on access to quality data and information, which can influence decisions related to land use, development, and ecological
conservation [22]. An in-depth review of data analysis in spatial planning projects reveals various challenges and opportunities. For
instance, studies (e.g., Refs. [23,24,25,14,26,27]) have explored issues related to data quality, standardization, and the use of
Geographic Information Systems (GIS) in spatial planning. These works underscore the importance of robust data analysis for informed
decision-making. In addition to data analysis, the role of spatial knowledge (including expert, tacit, sectoral, and community
knowledge) in urban development has gained attention [8]. Research has explored methods for participatory data collection and
analysis to integrate diverse forms of knowledge into planning processes. Advances in (geo)information technology have expanded
opportunities for spatial knowledge production, although questions regarding access and inclusivity remain [8].
Issues of knowledge management are also prominent in urban development and spatial planning research [28,19]. These studies
delve into topics such as citizen participation through social networks, ontologies-based approaches to planning, and the integration of
human knowledge and artificial intelligence in geographic knowledge systems. Document management, a critical aspect of spatial
planning information management, is examined in a study proposing a spatial document management system [29]. This system
simplifies the handling of spatial documents and enhances information accessibility. Communication within spatial planning projects
is another key area of investigation. Improved communication can foster citizen engagement and a deeper understanding of devel-
opment plans [30]. Effective communication management systems are essential for stakeholder engagement in urban infrastructure
projects [31]. Furthermore, comparative studies have examined public communication in urban planning practices in different regions
[32].
The enhanced literature review underscores several key insights that not only enrich the understanding of information manage-
ment in spatial planning projects but also lay the groundwork for research activities. Through a meticulous analysis of previous works,
it was uncovered a multifaceted landscape where information management encompasses various dimensions, including document
management, communication management, knowledge management, and data management. This nuanced understanding allows to
approach research with a holistic perspective, recognizing the intricate interplay of these facets within spatial planning projects.
3.2. Problem state-of-art review
Launched in December 2018 and coordinated by the CARTIF Technology Centre, the MAKING-CITY project has undertaken a 60-
month endeavor to implement advanced methodologies based on the Positive Energy District (PED) concept. In the context of this

project, a PED is defined as a district that achieves net zero energy import and net zero carbon emissions annually while working
towards generating a surplus of renewable energy locally. The primary objectives of the project include demonstrating the PED concept
in selected Lighthouse cities, Groningen and Oulu, and subsequently developing a validated procedure for its implementation in six
additional cities. To support this, the project aims to establish business models that integrate PED deployment and stimulate the
creation of a business ecosystem around the concept. Furthermore, the project will assist in aligning with the City Vision 2050 and mid-
term goals by providing methodologies and procedures for PED implementation within the 2030 timescale. MAKING-CITY also plans
to engage in social innovation activities to identify business opportunities related to PED integration, involving industrial players,
SMEs, and NGOs. A robust communication and dissemination strategy will be employed to promote and raise awareness of the
developed PED concept, fostering cooperation with related projects and relevant clusters. As a result, the project is expected to have
significant impacts, including increased use of renewables, reduced greenhouse gas emissions, improved energy efficiency, enhanced
energy balance, and greater adoption of electric mobility solutions. It will also contribute to improved urban air quality, transform
local economies, and generate employment, with over 4358 jobs anticipated in the eight cities initially involved. Replicating the PED
concept in at least 20 other European cities could create an additional 14,500 jobs. MAKING-CITY aims to mobilize public and private
investments through validated PED replication and innovative business models, paving the way for broader PED implementation,
supported by technical feasibility, suitable business models, and societal acceptance. The MAKING-CITY consortium comprises 34
partners, including city councils, universities, research centers, clusters, housing administrators, SMEs, energy companies, and con-
struction firms, pooling their expertise for the pro#ject's success.

Given the large number of stakeholders, project participants, and data that are the main resources of a project, the problem of
information management in a project is a relevant one.
The success of the MAKING-CITY project directly depends on the quality of the information used to create the urban development
model of Groningen, Bassano del Grappo, Leon, Trenčin, Oulu, Kadıkoy, Lublin, Vidin. Regarding the specific MAKING-CITY, when it is
developed as a model of an urban environment with the PED concept, the tasks related to the collection, processing, exchange,
dissemination, and storage of information are the basic needs of the project.
So, the information needs of the MAKING-CITY project are [33].
-Information collection: city-related, multisource data
-Information analysis: complex information processing
-External cooperation -public involvement
-Internal cooperation between government departments
-Openness: transparency in urban planning management
-Fairness: multi-dimensional considerations, the pursuit of equality
-Adaptability: adjust the planning direction and methods according to recent circumstances
In the context of spatial planning projects, exemplified by the international project MAKING-CITY, the exchange, dissemination,
and management of information face substantial challenges. The existing information exchange framework lacks seamless integration,
leading to fragmented information-sharing processes among project participants and stakeholders. Currently, project information is
spread across multiple platforms, including a cloud-based document repository, email, MS Teams, and the project website, without
effective interconnectivity. This fragmentation hampers efficient collaboration and obstructs comprehensive monitoring of project

MAKING-CITY's Collaboration Secretariat has specific objectives to enhance knowledge information flow, recognizing that

In the results of project implementation authors defined a significant level of dissatisfaction with the prevailing information
management processes and technologies. This discontentment can be attributed to several key factors that collectively underscore the
urgent need for reform in spatial planning projects like MAKING-CITY.
Firstly, one of the primary sources of frustration has been the limited collaborative capabilities within the existing information
management framework. Project participants have expressed concerns regarding the difficulty of working together seamlessly.
Collaborative efforts often encounter roadblocks due to the disjointed nature of the current information system. This limitation not

Secondly, the constraints in disseminating project outcomes have been a focal point of dissatisfaction. The project's success hinges
on the effective communication of findings, solutions, and progress to relevant stakeholders. However, the current information
management setup falls short in this regard. Project outcomes struggle to reach the intended audiences in a timely and comprehensive

Thirdly, inadequate functionalities for managing document flow have been a recurring issue. In a complex spatial planning project

project participants face challenges in organizing, tracking, and accessing critical information. This deficiency not only increases the
risk of errors and oversights but also consumes valuable time and resources.
The complexity and multitude of interactions inherent in such projects underscore the urgency of establishing a unified information
space to minimize errors, delays, and the potential failure of information to reach its intended recipients in a timely and effective

4. Results
4.1. Conceptual model of the information management system
Based on the author's experience, the analyzed articles, and previous studies [36,37,38,39], a conceptual model for an information
management system of spatial planning projects has been developed.
First, let's consider the glossary of the model.
Definition 1. The Spatial Planning Information Management System (SPIMS) is a comprehensive system designed to facilitate
the effective planning, collection, storage, processing, dissemination, and control of digital project information within the context of
spatial planning projects.
SPIMS will be represented as consisting of the SPIMS entities (Table 1).
The SPIMS manages any information produced by the project's information systems and used outside of those systems. Its main
purpose is to manage the processes of creating and using digital information in the spatial planning project.
SPIMS functions.
-planning the receiving of information resources;
-planning the exchange of information resources;
-electronic accounting of incoming information resources (including electronic ones produced by the IS);
-fast searching for required information resources;
-control of work with information resources (including receipt and execution of orders);
-control of the flow of information resources.
SPIMS -is a complex system, and therefore its effective functioning requires the timely and coherent interaction of all its elements,
which is impossible without good management of information resources.
Definition 2. Information Resource (IR) -any information that is obtained in the project or from the external environment and
used to produce a project product or intermediate deliverable.
The following types of information resources are identified for spatial planning projects.
-Document -officially approved and recorded in specific form information intended for management of the spatial planning project.
-Project data -data obtained during the implementation of the project, which is intended to obtain the product of the project.
-Dissemination information -project information intended to be shared with stakeholders or others to make them aware of the
project results.
-Knowledge -useful information directly or indirectly acquired as a result of the project, which may be fully or partially used for
other processes or projects.

-Communication information -information necessary for communication between project participants and stakeholders.
In essence, the SPIMS is a set of components such as document management, knowledge management, data management, and
project communication management linked by project information resources. Each component may contain different information
systems.
Definition 3. Document management is a systematic process for the creation, storage, organization, retrieval, sharing, and control
of electronic and physical documents within an organization. Its primary purpose is to efficiently manage documents throughout their
lifecycle, ensuring they are easily accessible, secure, and compliant with regulatory requirements.
Definition 4. Knowledge management is the systematic process of identifying, capturing, storing, organizing, retrieving, and
sharing an organization's knowledge (employee expertise, product knowledge, customer knowledge, intellectual property, best
practices, etc.) and information assets to support its objectives and improve decision-making.
Definition 5. Data management is the process of collecting, storing, organizing, and maintaining data (financial data, website
analytics, logistics, and transportation data) in a structured and secure manner to ensure its accuracy, availability, and usability for
various business purposes and decision-making. It encompasses activities such as data collection, data storage, data integration, data
quality assurance, and data security to maximize the value and reliability of an organization's data assets.
Definition 6. Communication management refers to the strategic planning, execution, and coordination of communication ac-
tivities within an organization or project. It involves the development of communication strategies, messaging, and channels to ensure
that information is effectively conveyed to the right stakeholders at the right time.
In addition to the components outlined above, the information management system should be implemented on three planes:
organisation, methodology, and technology (Fig. 3)
1. Organisation of the information management system:
-identification of responsibility for the management, administration, and coordination in the SPIMS;
-modification of the information interaction processes in the project by the SPIMS procedures.
2. Information management system methodology:
-definition and approval of rules and procedures for the collection, processing, storing, transfer, etc. information resources in
spatial planning projects;

3. Information management system technology:
-development and implementation of a tool (information technology) that technically connects project participants and stake-

Effective information management involves a holistic approach that encompasses three key components: methodology, organi-
zation, and technology. Methodology refers to the set of processes and procedures that govern how information is collected, processed,
stored, and disseminated throughout the project lifecycle. This includes defining the rules of information interaction between project
participants and stakeholders, as well as the responsible persons who will oversee the implementation of these rules. Organization, on
the other hand, focuses on the structure of the project team and how information is distributed among its members. It involves
identifying the key stakeholders and defining their roles and responsibilities in the management of project information. This includes
establishing communication channels and protocols, setting up reporting mechanisms, and defining workflows and decision-making
processes. Also, technology plays a crucial role in the effective management of project information by providing tools and platforms
that simplify the processes of collecting, processing, storing, and disseminating data. This includes the use of databases, project
management software, collaborative platforms, and other digital tools that enable real-time data sharing and analysis. By leveraging
technology, project teams can streamline their workflows and improve their ability to collaborate and make informed decisions based
on accurate and up-to-date information. Overall, an effective information management strategy requires the careful integration of
these three key components to ensure the success of the project.
Based on the proposed conceptual framework, system components, and implementation planes, a conceptual model of the infor-
mation management system of spatial planning projects "Hourglass" was developed (Fig. 4). The model is called an hourglass because
of the property of the information resource to flow from the actor to the information systems and back through the neck of the hub like
sand is poured in an hourglass.
The Hourglass model shows the information management system in spatial planning projects through the relationship between
actors, information systems, and the external environment in the context of SPIMS components. This relationship is the exchange of
information resources between system elements through the information hub of the SPIMS. An information hub (Info Hub) is an
information technology that acts as a link between system actors and information systems. In essence, through the use of this hub, an
actor can.
-submit an inquiry and obtain the necessary information;
-upload information to information systems.
An Information Hub is a centralized platform that serves as a focal point for the aggregation, organization, exchange, and distri-
bution of data and information within an organization or network. Information Hubs are designed to facilitate seamless communi-
cation and data flow between various systems, applications, databases, and stakeholders, often acting as intermediaries to ensure that
information reaches its intended destination efficiently and securely. Instead of necessitating direct connections between all actors and
project stakeholders, which can be cumbersome and prone to errors, the hub acts as a single node through which all communication
flows. This streamlines the entire process, significantly reducing the time required for both sending and receiving information within
the project. Moreover, it plays a crucial role in error reduction, as it minimizes the complexity associated with multiple, potentially
error-prone connections. In the context of external information resources, the Information Hub plays a dual role in facilitating seamless
interactions. When external information is submitted to the project, it follows a structured path, beginning with the External

5. Discussion
The conceptual model of information management systems presented in this study, utilizing the MAKING-CITY project as a case
study, offers valuable insights into the complexities and challenges of managing information in spatial planning projects. With its
diverse array of stakeholders and lack of a unified information management system, MAKING-CITY serves as an apt example for
exploring these issues, which are prevalent in many spatial planning endeavors.
The proposed conceptual model, termed SPIMS, addresses the need for a centralized information management environment by
integrating various information systems, project participants, and stakeholders. The main advantages of SPIMS are.
1. Localisation of IS information management functions in the SPIMS, which allows the entire information environment of the project
to be easily tailored to the needs of the users.
2. Created and implemented new IS are not adjusted to the databases and knowledge bases of other IS. Their integration is based on
the macro-description of the project's information technology performed in the SPIMS.

Therefore, its application should be context-specific, considering project characteristics and potential.
Consequently, the developed conceptual model for information management systems in spatial planning projects holds significant
importance for both theory and practice. This model offers a structured framework that enhances our understanding of how infor-
mation resources can be effectively managed in complex spatial planning projects. From a theoretical perspective, it enriches the field
of information management by providing a tailored framework for spatial planning, addressing the unique challenges in this domain.
In practice, this model offers several managerial implications. Firstly, it empowers organizations involved in spatial planning
projects to streamline their information management processes, reducing redundancy, errors, and inefficiencies. It also aids in the
integration of various information systems, leading to better collaboration among project participants. Moreover, the model em-
phasizes the importance of data quality, which can significantly improve decision-making in spatial planning projects. For decision-
makers and policymakers, this study provides valuable insights into optimizing information management in spatial planning. By
adopting the proposed model, decision-makers can ensure that the right information is available to the right stakeholders at the right
time, facilitating informed and timely decisions. Additionally, the model's emphasis on adaptability to external environmental changes
can help policymakers develop strategies that are more resilient in the face of evolving challenges such as climate change and
urbanization.
The proposed conceptual model is an idea that allows the creation of tools that will serve as the technological infrastructure that
supports the systematic organization, control, and dissemination of information in alignment with the principles of information
management, thereby ensuring the efficient operation of spatial planning projects.
6. Conclusions
This study delineates the crucial aspects of information management systems in spatial planning projects, using the MAKING-CITY
project as a focal point. It proposes a comprehensive conceptual model, SPIMS, to address information management challenges,
emphasizing the need for technological, methodological, and organizational solutions. The research underscores the growing
importance of information management in contemporary spatial planning endeavors and advocates for further exploration into
emerging technologies, cybersecurity, and user experience. These efforts are vital for advancing urban development processes in an
increasingly information-driven world.
